et: Middle English {it}corounen, crounen,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}coroner, corouner,{/it} going back to Latin {it}corōnare{/it} "to deck with garlands, wreath, encircle," derivative of {it}corōna{/it} "wreathe, garland worn on the head as a mark of honor or emblem of majesty" {ma}{mat|crown:1|}{/ma}

et: Middle English {it}coroune, croune,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}corone, coroune,{/it} going back to Latin {it}corōna{/it} "wreath, garland worn on the head as a mark of honor or emblem of majesty," borrowed from Greek {it}korṓnē{/it} "crow, seabird (perhaps a shearwater), any of various curved or hooked objects (as a door handle or tip of a bow), kind of crown," perhaps formed from an original n-stem nominative {it}*kor-ōn{/it} "crow, seabird," from a base {it}*kor-{/it} {ma}{mat|cornice|}{/ma}

Old English {it}corona{/it} "crown," a weak noun borrowed directly from Latin, may have been replaced by the Anglo-French word if it was continued into Middle English at all. Ancient Greek {it}korṓnē,{/it} though marginally attested in the meaning "crown, garland" (as something bent or curved?), is nonetheless presumed to be the source of the Latin word; aside from a gloss "kind of crown" ({it}eîdos stephánou{/it}) by the lexicographer Hesychius, this sense is known only from a single fragment, of doubtful interpretation, by Sophron of Syracuse, a writer of mime. As both Sophron and the lyric poet Stesichorus, who used the derivative {it}korōnís{/it} "garland," wrote in Doric, it is possible that the meaning "garland," whatever its origin, was peculiar to western dialects of Greek and hence transmitted to Latin.
shortdef: a reward of victory or mark of honor; especially : the title representing the championship in a sport
a royal or imperial headdress or cap of sovereignty : diadem

dt: {bc}a British coin worth two shillings and sixpence used as legal tender until 1970

dt: {bc}an unofficial title in horse racing representing the championship achieved by a horse that wins the three classic races for a designated category

{bc}a set of three noteworthy awards, wins, or achievements in a particular field
